technical-data.invention-title: Verfahren und Vorrichtung zur Regelung des Energieverbrauchs von Mobil-Stationen in einem CSMA/CA-drahtlosen LAN.
Method and apparatus for controlling power consumption of stations on CSMA/CA-based wireless LAN
Procèdè et dispositif pour le contrôle de la consommation de puissance de stations mobiles dans un réseau local sans fil du typ CSMA/CA

address.street: Elkington and Fife LLP Prospect House 8 Pembroke Road

description.p: The present invention relates to a method and apparatus for controlling the power consumption of stations on a carrier sense multiple access/collision avoidance (CSMA/CA)-based wireless local area network (LAN), and more particularly, to a method and apparatus for controlling the power consumption of stations in a CSMA/CA-based wireless LAN system when the stations are in a standby mode for receiving a wireless signal from each other.

Wireless local area network (LAN) systems based on the IEEE 802.11 standard employ carrier sense multiple access/collision avoidance (CSMA/CA) to share a wireless medium with one another. FIG. 1 is a schematic diagram illustrating a wireless LAN system based on the IEEE 802.11 standard. Referring to FIG. 1, the wireless LAN system includes a basic service set (BSS) 10, the Internet 11, and a content server 12.

The BSS 10 includes a wireless terminal 101 and an access point (AP) 102. A wireless terminal 101, which is a type of subscriber terminal requesting wireless LAN services, is called a station. The AP 102 is connected to a wired network, such as the Internet 11, or is wired, via a distribution system (DS), to another AP (not shown) that constitutes another BSS so that the AP 102 can bridge the Internet 11 and another network.

The station, i.e., the wireless terminal 101, has a hierarchical structure shown in FIG. 2. Referring to FIG. 2, the station includes a radio frequency (RF) layer 20, a baseband layer 21, and a media access control (MAC) layer 22. Here, the RF layer 20 and the baseband layer 21 are called physical layers.

The MAC layer 22 receives carrier sense information from the physical layers, i.e., the RF layer 20 and the baseband layer 21, and determines, based on the received carrier sense information, whether a wireless medium is currently being used before transmitting a frame to a receiving station. If the wireless medium is in an idle state, a sending station transmits the frame to the receiving station. All stations within a propagation range of the sending station can determine whether the wireless medium is being used when the frame is transmitted thereto by referring to a duration field value of the frame. The receiving station, which receives the frame from the sending station, transmits an acknowledgement (ACK) frame to the sending station, a process which is illustrated in FIG. 3A. Writing the time of use of the wireless medium into a frame and transmitting the frame is called virtual carrier sense.

Since wireless LAN systems are mainly employed in portable or mobile devices, battery power has always been an important issue to be dealt with. Current wireless LAN systems consume about 80% or more of their energy while performing operations on the physical layers.

In order to minimize power consumption, stations adopt a power management program so that they can operate with low power consumption. The power management program is used in an infrastructure network using the AP 102. Power management of the stations can be carried out every predetermined number of beacon cycles by using the power management program. Each beacon cycle lasts for an average of 100 msec. During the exchange of power management frames in a network, the AP 102 needs to buffer the power management frames, which makes it impossible to control power of the station every 100 msec or less. Therefore, if a station consumes too much power during a real-time bi-directional service, such as a voice/video call, it cannot properly provide the real-time bi-directional service.

FIG. 3B is a timing diagram illustrating a virtual carrier sense operation performed by stations in a wireless LAN environment. Referring to FIG. 3B, first through third stations STA-1, STA-2, and STA-3 and other stations periodically perform virtual carrier sense operations to share a wireless medium. For example, in a case where the first station STA-1 transmits (30) a frame to the third station STA-3, the second station STA-2 and the other stations, which are not the target stations for the frame consume as much power as they carry out a virtual carrier sense operation (31). In response to the receipt of the frame, the third station STA-3 transmits (32) an ACK message, which indicates that no error has occurred in the received frame, to the first station STA-1. The second station STA-2 and the other stations also carry out the virtual carrier sense (33).
Therefore, each of the second station STA-2 and the other stations unnecessarily consumes as much power as the first station STA-1 does.

Stations constituting a wireless LAN system consume power when transmitting and receiving frames to and from one another or carrying out a virtual carrier sense operation. Each of the stations consumes 30 - 50 % more power when transmitting a frame than when receiving a frame. In addition, each of the stations consumes power only for transmitting a frame after performing a carrier sense operation. When performing the carrier sense operation, each of the stations consumes as much power as they receive a frame. In a case where a plurality of stations share a wireless medium, however, they consume more power when carrying out a carrier sense operation than when transmitting a frame. For example, in a case where 20 or more stations share a single wireless medium for a predetermined amount of time, they consume at least 10 times more power when carrying out a virtual carrier sense operation than when transmitting a frame. Therefore, in a wireless network structure, such as a hot spot, in which a plurality of stations are served by one AP, the plurality of stations consume most of their power carrying out a virtual carrier sense operation. Consequently, it is necessary to reduce the power consumption of the plurality of stations consumed when the plurality of stations carry out the virtual carrier sense.

US 6 580 700 discloses a wireless LAN in which data rate is analysed by a mobile unit to indentify the most eligible access point at the highest data rate. The article "Evaluating the Energy-Consumption Reduction in a MANET by Dynamically Switching-off Network Interfaces" by Juan-Carlos Cano et al., Computers and Communications, 2001, XP010552533, pp 186-191 discloses a power conserving algorithm in which network interface cards are dynamically switched off.
According to the invention, there is provided a method of controlling the power consumption of a station as defined in claim 1.
The invention also provides an apparatus for controlling the power consumption of a station as claimed in claim 5.

The invention provides a method and apparatus that reduce power consumed by stations to carry out a virtual carrier sense operation by powering down all elements of each of the stations except for only a few that are important for stabilizing each of the stations after power is applied to each of the stations.
The present invention will now be described more fully with reference to the accompanying drawings, in which exemplary embodiments of the invention are shown.

FIG. 4 is a block diagram illustrating a hierarchical structure of a station according to a preferred embodiment of the present invention. Referring to FIG. 4, the hierarchical structure of the station includes a radio frequency (RF) layer 41, a baseband layer 42, and a media access control (MAC) layer 43. The RF layer 41 includes an RF/IF signal processor 411, which receives an RF signal via an antenna 40, converts the received RF signal into an intermediate frequency (IF) signal, and converts the IF signal into a baseband signal, a voltage controlled oscillator-phase locked loop (VCO-PLL) 412, which provides a reference frequency to the RF/IF signal processor 411, and a first register 413, which stores data necessary for the operation of the RF/IF signal processor 411 and provides the data to the RF/IF signal processor 411.

The baseband layer 42 includes an analog-to-digital converter 421, which converts the baseband signal output from the RF/IF signal processor 411 into a digital signal, a baseband signal processor 422, which demodulates the digital signal output from the analog-to-digital converter 421 using a demodulation method, such as a frequency-shift keying (FSK) method, thereby recovering the original signal, and a second register 423, which stores data necessary for the operation of the analog-to-digital converter 421 and the baseband signal processor 422 and provides the data to the analog-digital converter 421 and the baseband signal processor 422.

The MAC layer 43 includes a MAC service access point (SAP) 431, which receives frames from the baseband signal processor 422, a received power controller 433, which controls power of the station based on frames received from the MAC SAP 431, and a frame processor 432, which communicates with a host (not shown) by carrying out protocol control or direct memory access.

When receiving a signal, power of the station is controlled in the following manner. FIG. 5 is a diagram illustrating a method of controlling power according to a preferred embodiment of the present invention. More specifically, FIG. 5 illustrates the operation of the received power controller 433.

Referring to FIG. 5, the received power controller 433 receives a PLCP frame and a MAC frame via the MAC SAP 431 in step 50. The PLCP frame and the MAC frame include various information, including header information and MAC frame transmission speed information. FIG. 6 illustrates the structure of a PLCP data unit (PPDU). Referring to FIG. 6, the PPDU includes a PLCP preamble, a PLCP header, and a MAC sublayer protocol data unit (MPDU). In FIG. 6, a synchronization field (sync) is used for obtaining incoming signals and synchronizing the incoming signals, and a start-of-frame-delimiter field (SFD) includes information indicating a beginning point in the PPDU. A signal field (SIGNAL) indicates an adopted modulation scheme, and a service field (SERVICE) is a reserved field. A length field (LENGTH) indicates an amount of time required to transmit the MPDU, and a cyclical redundancy check (CRC) field has a frame check sequence (FCS) value calculated by a transmitting station. The PLCP preamble and the PLCP header can be transmitted at a speed of 1 Mbps, and the MPDU can be transmitted at a speed of 1 or 2 Mbps.

In step 51, the received power controller 433 extracts transmission speed information and frame transmission period information from the information received in step 50. In step 52, the received power controller 433 determines a power-controlled period, by interpreting the extracted information. The frame transmission period information can be obtained from a duration field of each MAC frame.

FIGS. 7(a) through 7(c) illustrate different examples of MAC frames. More specifically, FIG. 7(a) illustrates the structure of a request-to-send (RTS) frame, FIG. 7(b) illustrates the structure of a clear-to-send (CTS) frame, and FIG. 7(c) illustrates the structure of a data frame. In FIGS. 7(a) through 7(c), RA represents a reception address, and TA represents a transmission address. In FIG. 7(c), ADDRESSES 1 through 4 are address fields, which can be respectively classified as one of a transmission address, a reception address, and a group address.

A power-controlled period for the baseband layer 42 is calculated independently of a power-controlled period for the RF layer 41 because the time taken for the baseband layer 42 to stabilize differs from the time taken for the RF layer 41 to stabilize. For example, given the current level of technology, it takes the baseband layer 42 no more than 5 microseconds to stabilize, while it takes the RF layer 41 no more than 10 microseconds to stabilize.

Once the power-controlled period of the baseband layer 42 and the RF layer 42 is determined, the received power controller 433 compares its address with a reception address of the received MAC frame in step 53. If the reception address of the received MAC frame is identical to the address of the received power controller 433, the method returns to step 50, a PLCP is continuously received, and the frame processor 432 performs an operation. In step 53, if the reception address of the received MAC frame is different from the address of the received power controller 433 in step 53, the received power controller 433 switches current modes of the baseband layer 42 and the RF layer 41 to low power modes during the power-controlled period determined in step 52. When the baseband layer 42 is in a low power mode, all the elements thereof except for the second register 423 are powered down and clocks provided thereto are all blocked. When the RF layer 41 is in the low power mode, all the elements thereof, except for the VCO-PLL 412 and the first register 413, are powered down. The first and second registers 413 and 423 and the VCO-PLL 412 are preferably continuously supplied with power because they require more time to stabilize after they are powered than the rest of the baseband layer 42 and the RF layer 41.

When power is cut off, the received power controller 433 counts the power-controlled period in step 55. If the power-controlled period of the RF layer 41 is over, the received power controller 433 applies power to the RF layer 41 so that the RF layer 41 can be switched from the low power mode to a normal operational mode. Once the RF layer 41 is powered, it stabilizes within 10 microseconds.

When the RF layer 41 returns to the normal operational mode and the power-controlled period of the baseband layer 42 is over, the received power controller 433 applies power to the baseband layer 42 so that the baseband layer 42 can be switched from the low power mode to the normal operational mode. Once the baseband layer 42 is powered, it stabilizes within 5 microseconds.
Thereafter, the method returns to step 50, in which the received power controller 433 continuously receives a PLCP, and the receiving station carries out a carrier sense operation.

FIG. 8 is a diagram illustrating the power consumption of stations when carrying out a carrier sense operation using a method of controlling power consumption of stations according to a preferred embodiment of the present invention. Referring to FIG. 8, when a first station STA-1 transmits (80) a MAC frame to a third station STA-3, a second station STA-2 and other stations, like the third station STA-3, carry out a carrier sense operation (81) so that they consume as much power as the third station STA-3. However, once the second station STA-2 and the other stations determine that the MAC frame is not directed thereto, they shift a current mode of each layer to a low power mode (82). When the third station STA-3 transmits (83) an ACK frame to the first station STA-1, the second station STA-2 and the other stations also carry out a virtual carrier sense (84). However, once the second station STA-2 and the other stations determine that the ACK frame is not directed thereto, they shift the current mode of each layer to the low power mode (85).

The method of controlling the power consumption of stations according to the preferred embodiment of the present invention was simulated under a circumstance where two stations and an AP were used in an Internet environment with some traffic. Simulation results show that the power consumption of stations in the present invention can be reduced to 30 - 50 % of the power consumption of stations in the prior art.

According to the present invention, it is possible to control the power consumption of stations in a hardware manner while the stations carry out a carrier sense operation. Thus, it is possible to minimize the power consumption of the stations in a bi-directional real-time communication service. The present invention complies with the IEEE 802.11 standard, and thus it can be readily applied to IEEE 802.11 wireless LAN systems. If the present invention is applied to a structure, into which a MAC layer, a baseband layer, and an RF layer are integrated in a silicon-on-chip manner, power conservation can be maximized. In addition, the present invention can be easily applied to field programmable gate arrays (FPGAs) or digital signal processors (DSPs).

claim.claim-text: Verfahren zum Steuern des Stromverbrauchs einer Station, wenn sie ein drahtloses Signal empfängt, unter Verwendung einer hierarchischen Struktur, die eine Hochfrequenzschicht (41) und eine Basisbandschicht (42) umfasst, wobei das Verfahren Folgendes umfasst: (51) Extrahieren von Frame-Übertragungsgeschwindigkeits-Informationen und Sendezeitraum-Informationen auf einer ersten Schicht (41), die eine Hochfrequenzschicht ist, und auf einer zweiten Schicht (42), die eine Basisbandschicht ist, aus dem drahtlosen Signal; (52) Bestimmen eines leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums für die erste und für die zweite Schicht anhand der extrahierten Informationen; und (54) Reduzieren des Stromverbrauchs der ersten und der zweiten Schicht durch Umschalten eines Strommodus der ersten und der zweiten Schicht in einen vorgegebenen Modus für die Dauer des leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums, wenn eine Empfangsadresse, die in den extrahierten Informationen enthalten ist, nicht mit einer Adresse der Station identisch ist.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1, wobei - in dem vorgegebenen Modus - einige Elemente der ersten und der zweiten Schicht (41, 42), die nach dem Einschalten weniger Zeit zum Stabilisieren brauchen als andere Elemente der ersten und der zweiten Schicht, abgeschaltet werden.

Verfahren nach Anspruch 1 oder 2, das des Weiteren Folgendes umfasst: (52) Zählen des leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums für die erste und für die zweite Schicht; (56) Zurückversetzen der ersten Schicht in ihren Ursprungsmodus, wenn der leistungsgesteuerte Zeitraum für die erste Schicht vorüber ist; und (57) Zurückversetzen der zweiten Schicht in ihren Ursprungsmodus, wenn der leistungsgesteuerte Zeitraum für die zweite Schicht vorüber ist.

Verfahren nach einem der vorangehenden Ansprüche, wobei, wenn die in den ausgeschlossenen Informationen enthaltene Empfangsadresse mit der Adresse der Station identisch ist, die Station das drahtlose Signal über die erste und die zweite Schicht empfängt.

Vorrichtung zum Steuern des Stromverbrauchs einer Station, wenn sie ein drahtloses Signal empfängt, unter Verwendung einer hierarchischen Struktur, wobei die Vorrichtung Folgendes umfasst: eine erste Schicht (41), die eine Hochfrequenzschicht ist und die das drahtlose Signal in ein Basisbandsignal umwandelt; eine zweite Schicht (42), die eine Basisbandschicht ist und die ein Ursprungssignal aus dem Basisbandsignal wiederherstellt; und ein Empfangsleistungsregler (433), wobei der Empfangsleistungsregler (433) für Folgendes ausgelegt ist: Empfangen von Frame-Übertragungsgeschwindigkeits-Informationen und Sendezeitraum-Informationen auf der ersten und der zweiten Schicht (41, 42) aus dem drahtlosen Signal; Bestimmen eines leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums für die erste und für die zweite Schicht anhand der Informationen; und Reduzieren des Stromverbrauchs der ersten und der zweiten Schicht (41, 42) durch Umschalten eines Strommodus für die Dauer des leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums der ersten und der zweiten Schicht zu einem vorgegebenen Modus, wenn eine Empfangsadresse, die in den Informationen enthalten ist, nicht mit einer Adresse der Station identisch ist.

Vorrichtung nach Anspruch 5, wobei die erste Schicht (41) Folgendes umfasst: einen Signalprozessor (411), der das drahtlose Signal in das Basisbandsignal umwandelt; eine Referenzfrequenz-Ausgabeeinheit (412), die eine Referenzfrequenz an den Signalprozessor ausgibt; und ein erstes Register (413), das Daten speichert, die für den Betrieb des Signalprozessors benötigt werden, wobei der Empfangsleistungsregler (433) nur dann Strom in die Referenzfrequenz-Ausgabeeinheit (412) und das erste Register (413) einspeist, wenn der Strommodus der ersten und der zweiten Schicht in den vorgegebenen Modus umgeschaltet wurde.

Vorrichtung nach Anspruch 5 oder 6, wobei die zweite Schicht (42) Folgendes umfasst: einen Analog-Digital-Wandler (421), der das Basisbandsignal in ein digitales Signal umwandelt; einen Basisbandsignalprozessor (422), der das Ursprungssignal aus dem digitalen Signal wiederherstellt; und ein zweites Register (423), das Daten speichert, die für den Betrieb des Analog-Digital-Wandlers oder des Basisbandsignalprozessors benötigt werden, wobei der Empfangsleistungsregler (433) nur dann Strom in das zweite Register (423) einspeist, wenn der Strommodus der ersten und der zweiten Schicht in den vorgegebenen Modus umgeschaltet wurde.

Vorrichtung nach Anspruch 5, 6 oder 7, wobei der Empfangsleistungsregler (433) einen leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraum für die erste und für die zweite Schicht anhand des wiederhergestellten Ursprungssignals bestimmt und den Strommodus der ersten und der zweiten Schicht während des leistungsgesteuerten Zeitraums in den vorgegebenen Modus umschaltet.

A method of controlling the power consumption of a station when it receives a wireless signal using a hierarchical structure comprising a radio frequency layer (41) and a baseband layer (42), the method comprising: (51) extracting information on frame transmission speed and transmission period information on a first, radio frequency, layer (41) and on a second, baseband, layer (42) from the wireless signal; (52) determining a power-controlled period for each of the first and second layers based on the extracted information; and (54) reducing the power consumption of the first and second layers by switching a current mode of the first and second layers to a predetermined mode for the power-controlled period if a reception address included in the extracted information is not identical to an address of the station.

The method of claim 1, wherein in the predetermined mode, some elements of the first and second layers (41,42),which require less time to be stabilized after being powered than other elements of the first and second layers, are powered down.

The method of claim 1 or 2, further comprising: (52) counting the power-controlled period for each of the first and second layers; (56) returning the first layer to its original mode if the power-controlled period for the first layer is over; and (57) returning the second layer to its original mode if the power-controlled period for the second layer is over.

The method of any preceding claim, wherein if the reception address included in the excluded information is identical to the address of the station, the station receives the wireless signal via the first and second layers.

An apparatus for controlling the power consumption of a station when it receives a wireless signal using a hierarchical structure, the apparatus comprising: a first, radio frequency layer (41), which converts the wireless signal into a baseband signal; a second, baseband layer (42), which restores an original signal from the baseband signal; and a received power controller (433), wherein the received power controller (433) is adapted to: receive information on frame transmission speed and transmission period information on the first and second layers (41,42) from the wireless signal; determine a power-controlled period for each of the first and second layers based on said information; and reduce the power consumed by the first and second layers (41,42) by switching a current mode for the power-controlled period of the first and second layers to a predetermined mode if a reception address included in said information is not identical with an address of the station.

The apparatus of claim 5, wherein the first layer (41) comprises: a signal processor (411), which converts the wireless signal into the baseband signal; a reference frequency provider (412), which provides the signal processor with a reference frequency; and a first register (413), which stores data necessary for the operation of the signal processor, where the received power controller (433) supplies power only to the reference frequency provider (412) and the first register (413) when the current mode of the first and second layers is switched to the predetermined mode.

The apparatus of claim 5 or 6, wherein the second layer (42) comprises: an analog-to-digital converter (421), which converts the baseband signal into a digital signal; a baseband signal processor (422), which restores the original signal from the digital signal; and a second register (423), which stores data necessary for the operation of the analog-to-digital converter or the baseband signal processor, where the received power controller (433) supplies power only to the second register (423) when the current mode of the first and second layers is switched to the predetermined mode.

The apparatus of claim 5, 6 or 7, wherein the received power controller (433) determines a power-controlled period for each of the first and second layers based on the restored original signal and switches the current mode of the first and second layers to the predetermined mode during the power-controlled period.

Procédé de régulation de la consommation de puissance d'une station lorsqu'elle reçoit un signal sans fil en utilisant une structure hiérarchique comprenant une couche de radiofréquences (41) et une couche de bande de base (42), le procédé comprenant : (51) l'extraction d'informations sur une vitesse de transmission de trame et d'informations de période de transmission sur une première couche de radiofréquences (41) et sur une deuxième couche de bande de base (42) à partir du signal sans fil ; (52) la détermination d'une période de régulation de puissance pour chacune de la première couche et de la deuxième couche sur la base des informations extraites ; et (54) la réduction de la consommation de puissance de la première couche et de la deuxième couche en commutant un mode actuel de la première couche et de la deuxième couche dans un mode prédéterminé pendant la période de régulation de puissance si une adresse de réception incluse dans les informations extraites n'est pas identique à une adresse de la station.

Procédé selon la revendication 1, dans lequel, dans le mode prédéterminé, certains éléments de la première couche et de la deuxième couche (41, 42), dont la stabilisation après la mise sous tension prend moins de temps que pour d'autres éléments de la première couche et de la deuxième couche, sont mis hors tension.

Procédé selon la revendication 1 ou 2, comprenant en outre : (52) le comptage de la période de régulation de puissance pour chacune de la première couche et de la deuxième couche ; (56) le retour de la première couche dans son mode d'origine si la période de régulation de puissance pour la première couche est terminée ; et (57) le retour de la deuxième couche dans son mode d'origine si la période de régulation de puissance pour la deuxième couche est terminée.

Procédé selon l'une quelconque des revendications précédentes, dans lequel, si l'adresse de réception incluse dans les informations exclues est identique à l'adresse de la station, la station reçoit le signal sans fil par l'intermédiaire de la première couche et de la deuxième couche.

Appareil pour réguler la consommation de puissance d'une station lorsqu'elle reçoit un signal sans fil en utilisant une structure hiérarchique, l'appareil comprenant : une première couche de radiofréquences (41) qui convertit le signal sans fil en un signal de bande de base ; une deuxième couche de bande de base (42) qui restaure un signal d'origine à partir du signal de bande de base ; et un organe de commande de puissance reçue (433), dans lequel l'organe de commande de puissance reçue (433) est apte à effectuer : la réception d'informations sur une vitesse de transmission de trame et d'informations de période de transmission sur la première couche et la deuxième couche (41, 42) à partir du signal sans fil ; la détermination d'une période de régulation de puissance pour chacune de la première couche et de la deuxième couche sur la base desdites informations ; et la réduction de la puissance consommée par la première couche et la deuxième couche (41, 42) en commutant un mode actuel pour la période de régulation de puissance de la première couche et de la deuxième couche dans un mode prédéterminé si une adresse de réception incluse dans lesdites informations n'est pas identique à une adresse de la station.

Appareil selon la revendication 5, dans lequel la première couche (41) comprend : un processeur de signal (411) qui convertit le signal sans fil en signal de bande de base ; un fournisseur de fréquence de référence (412), qui fournit une fréquence de référence au processeur de signal ; et un premier registre (413) qui mémorise les données nécessaires au fonctionnement du processeur de signal, dans lequel l'organe de commande de puissance reçue (433) fournit une puissance uniquement au fournisseur de fréquence de référence (412) et au premier registre (413) lorsque le mode actuel de la première couche et de la deuxième couche est commuté dans le mode prédéterminé.

Appareil selon la revendication 5 ou 6, dans lequel la deuxième couche (42) comprend : un convertisseur analogique-numérique (421) qui convertit le signal de bande de base en signal numérique ; un processeur de signal de bande de base (422) qui restaure le signal d'origine à partir du signal numérique ; et un deuxième registre (423) qui mémorise les données nécessaires au fonctionnement du convertisseur analogique-numérique ou du processeur de signal de bande de base, dans lequel l'organe de commande de puissance reçue (433) fournit une puissance uniquement au deuxième registre (423) lorsque le mode actuel de la première couche et de la deuxième couche est commuté dans le mode prédéterminé.

Appareil selon la revendication 5, 6 ou 7, dans lequel l'organe de commande de puissance reçue (433) détermine une période de régulation de puissance pour chacune de la première couche et de la deuxième couche sur la base du signal d'origine restauré et commute le mode actuel de la première couche et de la deuxième couche dans le mode prédéterminé au cours de la période de régulation de puissance.
